examples.query: Switch from beef to chicken twice a week
examples.description: Food substitution scenario: replacing beef meals with chicken

carbon.interpretation: Significant reduction primarily from eliminating cattle methane emissions

water.interpretation: Major water savings due to beef's high water footprint (15,400L/kg vs chicken's 4,325L/kg)

waste.interpretation: Minimal waste difference; slightly more packaging with chicken

keyInsights: Methane reduction is the biggest driver (~80% of carbon savings)
Water savings are substantial - equivalent to ~45 showers per week
Land use decreases significantly (less pasture needed)
Rebound effect: ~15-30% of savings may be offset by spending saved money elsewhere
reboundEffects: Rebound spending: May offset 15-30% of carbon savings
Feed crop demand shifts but doesn't eliminate agricultural impact

examples.query: Bike instead of Uber twice a week
examples.description: Transport substitution scenario: replacing rideshare trips with cycling

carbon.interpretation: Direct vehicle emissions avoided plus deadhead miles eliminated

water.interpretation: Minor water savings from reduced fuel production

waste.interpretation: Reduced vehicle maintenance waste (oil, tires, parts)

keyInsights: Deadhead miles (40% extra driving to pick you up) amplify the savings
Health co-benefits from exercise are significant but not quantified
Food intake increase from cycling has a small carbon offset
Cost savings of ~$25/week could fund other carbon-intensive activities
reboundEffects: Extra food consumption: +200 kcal/day × 2 = slight offset
Rebound travel: Saved money may fund additional trips

examples.query: What if my city bans single-use plastic bags?
examples.description: Policy scenario: city-wide ban on single-use plastic bags

carbon.interpretation: Modest per-person reduction; significant at city scale

water.interpretation: INCREASE - paper bags are more water-intensive to produce

waste.interpretation: Less plastic waste, but paper waste increases; net reduction due to biodegradability

keyInsights: Paper bags have higher production emissions than plastic (but biodegrade)
Reusable bags need ~40+ uses to break even on carbon
Ocean plastic leakage is significantly reduced
Behavioral change: people forget reusable bags ~20% of the time
reboundEffects: Bag forgetting: ~20% of shopping trips result in purchasing alternative
Thicker 'reusable' plastic bags may emerge as workaround
Paper bag production increases water usage

examples.query: What if 30% of students use reusable water bottles?
examples.description: Adoption scenario: partial adoption of reusable bottles in a student population

carbon.interpretation: Per-student reduction; multiply by student count for total

water.interpretation: Net water savings despite washing water use

keyInsights: Break-even point: reusable bottle needs ~20 uses to offset production
Most students exceed this within first month
Washing water (~0.5L/wash) is minor compared to bottled water footprint
Transportation emissions from shipping bottled water are eliminated
reboundEffects: Convenience purchases: ~10% of users occasionally buy bottled water
Water fountain demand increases (positive infrastructure effect)
